title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What is the fundamental counting principle in probability?

options.label: A
options.text: The probability of an event is always 1/2.

options.label: B
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A + B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: C
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A times B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: The probability of an event is always 1/5.

multiple-choice.question: A 10-question true/false quiz has how many possible combinations of answers?
What is the probability of getting a perfect score on a 10-question true/false quiz by randomly guessing?
What would be the most common score if you and all your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 10-question true/false quiz?
How do you find the average number of questions you would get right by guessing on a true/false quiz?

options.label: A
options.text: Multiply the number of questions by the probability of getting the question wrong.

options.label: B
options.text: Multiply the number of questions by the probability of getting the question right.

options.label: C
options.text: Add the number of questions to the probability of getting the question right.

options.label: D
options.text: Subtract the number of questions from the probability of getting the question right.

multiple-choice.question: If there are 20 questions on a multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question, what is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing?

options.label: C
options.text: 1/95 trillion

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected score on a 20-question multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question, assuming you randomly guess on all questions?

A standardized test like the SAT has 50 multiple-choice questions with 5 possible answers for each question. If you randomly guess on all questions, what is the expected number of questions you would get right?

Compare the probability of getting a perfect score on a 10-question true/false quiz by randomly guessing versus the probability of getting all 20 questions correct on a multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question. Which one is smaller?

options.label: A
options.text: The probability of getting a perfect score on the true/false quiz is smaller.

options.label: B
options.text: The probability of getting all 20 questions correct on the multiple-choice test is smaller.

options.label: C
options.text: They are equal.

options.label: D
options.text: Cannot be determined.

multiple-choice.question: Evaluate the effectiveness of randomly guessing on a true/false quiz versus studying for the quiz. Which approach is more effective?

options.label: A
options.text: Randomly guessing is more effective.

options.label: B
options.text: Studying is more effective.

options.label: C
options.text: They are equally effective.

options.label: D
options.text: Cannot be determined.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of authentic narrative in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide factual information quickly

options.label: B
options.text: To connect people and make a story timeless and humanistic

options.label: C
options.text: To promote a particular agenda or ideology

options.label: D
options.text: To entertain readers with trivial stories

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what are the three components of sourcing required in every well-reported piece of journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, unofficial sources, and social media

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

options.label: C
options.text: Academics, consultants, and authors

options.label: D
options.text: Stakeholders, experts, and witnesses

multiple-choice.question: What type of sources can provide the "why" behind an event or trend and its consequences on a personal level?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources

options.label: B
options.text: Overview sources

options.label: C
options.text: Unofficial sources

options.label: D
options.text: Social media sources

multiple-choice.question: How can journalists achieve a complicated, fragile human connection with their subjects?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking routine questions and taking notes

options.label: B
options.text: By regarding the stories of every subject as sacred and asking surprising questions

options.label: C
options.text: By focusing on facts and data

options.label: D
options.text: By using social media to gather information

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of anecdotes in storytelling, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide additional facts and data

options.label: B
options.text: To breathe life into a grey story of exposition

options.label: C
options.text: To summarize the main points of a story

options.label: D
options.text: To promote a particular agenda or ideology

multiple-choice.question: When is it important to convey information quickly in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: When telling a personal story

options.label: B
options.text: When presenting a profile of a person

options.label: C
options.text: When a situation is urgent and action is required

options.label: D
options.text: When writing a feature article

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using the "slow dance of information" in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows readers to quickly scan the article

options.label: B
options.text: It provides a comprehensive overview of the topic

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the journalism memorable and delivers a narrative bond

options.label: D
options.text: It is only suitable for trivial stories

multiple-choice.question: How can journalists identify what is compelling from what is chatter, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking routine questions and taking notes

options.label: B
options.text: By asking surprising questions and regarding the stories of every subject as sacred

options.label: C
options.text: By focusing on facts and data

options.label: D
options.text: By using social media to gather information

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of overview sources in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide the "why" behind an event or trend

options.label: B
options.text: To offer expertise and knowledge of the big picture

options.label: C
options.text: To promote a particular agenda or ideology

options.label: D
options.text: To summarize the main points of a story

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what makes a story timeless and humanistic?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of facts and data

options.label: B
options.text: The inclusion of personal anecdotes and narratives

options.label: C
options.text: The promotion of a particular agenda or ideology

options.label: D
options.text: The use of social media to gather information

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: Who said, "There is no frigate like a book to take us lands away..."?

options.label: A
options.text: Samuel Richardson

options.label: B
options.text: Emily Dickinson

options.label: C
options.text: Jane Austen

options.label: D
options.text: Charles Dickens

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what do researchers in psychology, neuroscience, child development, and biology have evidence for?

options.label: A
options.text: The negative impact of stories on people's point of view

options.label: B
options.text: The unique ability of stories to change a person's point of view

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of influence of stories on culture

options.label: D
options.text: The superiority of non-fiction over fiction

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of Samuel Richardson's "Pamela" on the literary world?

options.label: A
options.text: It was largely ignored by the public and critics

options.label: B
options.text: It caused a significant stir and sparked intense debate

options.label: C
options.text: It was praised for its traditional portrayal of class and marriage

options.label: D
options.text: It was only popular among the upper class

multiple-choice.question: How have novels helped shape the minds of thought leaders across history, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing a platform for them to express their ideas

options.label: B
options.text: By inspiring their theories and ideas through fictional plots

options.label: C
options.text: By offering a critique of their work

options.label: D
options.text: By providing a historical context for their ideas

multiple-choice.question: What is the alternative perspective on human nature mentioned in the transcript, contrasting with the idea of being a solitary hero?

options.label: A
options.text: Being a member of a shared quest

options.label: B
options.text: Being a solitary villain

options.label: C
options.text: Being a superior being

options.label: D
options.text: Being a passive observer

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's suggestion for readers who have "walked about 100 trillion miles" in the shoes of classic authors?

options.label: A
options.text: To stop reading the classics altogether

options.label: B
options.text: To only read modern literature

options.label: C
options.text: To continue reading the classics, but also be open to new perspectives and ideas

options.label: D
options.text: To only read non-fiction books

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential lesson that "Hunger Games" can teach readers, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of individualism over collectivism

options.label: B
options.text: The dangers of pursuing a perfect body

options.label: C
options.text: The need to rethink capitalism and prioritize the group over the individual

options.label: D
options.text: The superiority of the Capitol over the districts

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's final question to the reader, encouraging them to think about their next literary journey?

options.label: A
options.text: What book will you read next?

options.label: B
options.text: What story will you try on next?

options.label: C
options.text: What author will you explore next?

options.label: D
options.text: What genre will you try next?

multiple-choice.question: How have stories, according to the transcript, influenced our understanding of concepts like class, marriage, and gender?

options.label: A
options.text: By reinforcing traditional and outdated ideas

options.label: B
options.text: By shaping and revising our understanding of these concepts over time

options.label: C
options.text: By having no impact on our understanding of these concepts

options.label: D
options.text: By only reflecting the views of the upper class

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's view on the future of stories and their potential impact on readers?

options.label: A
options.text: That there are no new stories to be told

options.label: B
options.text: That stories will continue to influence and spark change in readers

options.label: C
options.text: That only classic literature has value

options.label: D
options.text: That readers should only focus on non-fiction books

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of using logarithms in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: To solve linear equations

options.label: B
options.text: To deal with extremely small or large numbers

options.label: C
options.text: To calculate geometric shapes

options.label: D
options.text: To analyze statistical data

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of an exponential equation?
What is the value of log base 10 of 10,000?
Why is it important to study logarithms, even if a calculator can compute them?

options.label: A
options.text: Because calculators are not always accurate

options.label: B
options.text: Because logarithms are only used in base 10

options.label: C
options.text: Because calculators only compute logarithms of base 10

options.label: D
options.text: Because logarithms are not useful in real-world applications

multiple-choice.question: What is the pH of a water sample with a hydrogen ion concentration of 0.0000000398?
How can logarithms be used in chemistry to find the pH of a water sample?

options.label: A
options.text: By using the formula pH = -log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: B
options.text: By using the formula pH = log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: C
options.text: By using the formula pH = -log base 2 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: D
options.text: By using the formula pH = log base 2 of the hydrogen ion concentration

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of 2 raised to the power of 6?
A water sample has a pH of 8.4. What effect is it likely to have on the eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: It will feel nice and soothing

options.label: B
options.text: It will have no effect

options.label: C
options.text: It will make the eyes feel itchy and red

options.label: D
options.text: It will cause permanent damage to the eyes

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the pH of a water sample and the hydrogen ion concentration?

options.label: A
options.text: As the pH increases, the hydrogen ion concentration also increases

options.label: B
options.text: As the pH decreases, the hydrogen ion concentration also decreases

options.label: C
options.text: As the pH increases, the hydrogen ion concentration decreases

options.label: D
options.text: As the pH decreases, the hydrogen ion concentration increases

multiple-choice.question: What is a real-world application of logarithms mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Calculating the area of a circle

options.label: B
options.text: Determining the pH of a water sample

options.label: C
options.text: Solving a system of linear equations

options.label: D
options.text: Finding the volume of a sphere

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What is the earliest known device used for telling time?

options.label: A
options.text: Sundial

options.label: B
options.text: Hourglass

options.label: C
options.text: Mechanical clock

options.label: D
options.text: Atomic clock

multiple-choice.question: How do sundials indicate time?

options.label: A
options.text: By casting a shadow onto a surface

options.label: B
options.text: By measuring the vibration of a quartz crystal

options.label: C
options.text: By counting the seconds based on atomic clocks

options.label: D
options.text: By burning down candles at predictable speeds

multiple-choice.question: What is a limitation of using sundials for telling time?

options.label: A
options.text: They require a power source

options.label: B
options.text: They are not portable

options.label: C
options.text: They require the sun to shine

options.label: D
options.text: They are not accurate

multiple-choice.question: Why were hourglasses commonly used on board ships?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were more accurate than sundials

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were not affected by the motion of the boat

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were easier to read

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were more portable

multiple-choice.question: What sparked a big change in traditional timekeeping methods in the 13th century?

options.label: A
options.text: The invention of the sundial

options.label: B
options.text: The invention of the hourglass

options.label: C
options.text: The invention of the mechanical clock

options.label: D
options.text: The invention of the atomic clock

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to keep track of time in modern society?

options.label: A
options.text: So we can accurately predict the weather

options.label: B
options.text: So we can communicate with people all over the world

options.label: C
options.text: So we can travel faster

options.label: D
options.text: So we can work longer hours

multiple-choice.question: What problem did the American railroad system face in the mid-19th century due to the lack of a standardized time system?

options.label: A
options.text: Trains were often late

options.label: B
options.text: Trains were often early

options.label: C
options.text: Different railroads had different times, causing confusion

options.label: D
options.text: Trains were not able to travel long distances

multiple-choice.question: How do time zones help to iron out differences in time between different locations?

options.label: A
options.text: By setting a uniform standard time for each region

options.label: B
options.text: By using a different time zone for each city

options.label: C
options.text: By ignoring the differences in time

options.label: D
options.text: By using a single time zone for the entire world

multiple-choice.question: If it is 12:00 PM in New York, and New York is 2 degrees (or 8 minutes) ahead of Boston, what time would it be in Boston?
Why do we have 40 time zones on land?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the earth is divided into 40 equal regions

options.label: B
options.text: Because the earliest and latest time zones are 26 hours apart

options.label: C
options.text: Because each country has its own time zone

options.label: D
options.text: Because the earth rotates 40 times in one day
